subject: Clarification on permits & assessments for 6-unit infill at [ADDRESS]

goals: Clarify required assessments and permit sequencing
constraints: Lane dedication covenant affects access geometry
blockers: Uncertainty on riparian trigger and QEP requirements
Uncertainty on parking vs access geometry impact
decision_points: Whether DP and BP can be submitted in parallel
Whether arborist report should precede stormwater layout

text:
Subject: Clarification on permits & assessments for 6-unit infill at [ADDRESS]

From: [NAME] <[EMAIL]>  | To: permits.navigator@gov.example.ca | Date: [DATE]
Hi team,
We’re scoping a 3-storey (6 units) infill on Lot 12, Block 3 at [ADDRESS]. Parcel ref: [PARCEL_ID].
Questions:
1) Do we need a Riparian Areas Protection Regulation assessment given a seasonal creek ~18m south of the lot?
2) Can we submit municipal DP and Building Permit in parallel if our zoning is compliant (R-2 infill)?
3) What is the sequence for stormwater review vs arborist report to minimize rework?
Attachments (drafts):
- [ATTACHMENT] 2025-02-10_CedarRidge_SitePlan_DRAFT.pdf
- [ATTACHMENT] 2025-02-10_Prelim_StormReport_MONROE.pdf
Thanks,
[NAME]  [PHONE]

Reply (Navigator):
- 18m proximity likely triggers riparian review; request QEP letter + SPEA mapping.
- DP before BP is preferred, but concurrent intake may be accepted with strong zoning conformity memo + coordinated civil package.
- Arborist report first so tree protection zones inform stormwater layout.
Request: share topo + QEP scoping letter for local nuance check.

Follow-up (Requester):
Question: rear lane dedication covenant [LEGAL]—impact on parking count or access geometry? Mixed guidance.

Reply (Navigator):
Covenant mainly impacts access geometry; stall counts per current zoning/bylaw. Will confirm with transportation reviewer.

subject: Re: File [FILE_NO] DP-24-1682 (1240 Willowbank Rd) – status & comments

goals: Unblock circulation and move toward clearance
constraints: Lane width fixed impacts fire access options
blockers: Stormwater calcs and testing requirements pending
Fire access swept path revisions required
decision_points: Whether mountable curb detail will satisfy Fire access
Whether timeline can meet financing expiry

text:
Subject: Re: File [FILE_NO] DP-24-1682 ([ADDRESS]) – status & comments

From: [NAME] <[EMAIL]> | To: permits.navigator@gov.example.ca | Date: [DATE]
Hi,
We’re at week 7 since intake for [FILE_NO]. Our lender is asking for updated milestones [FINANCING]. We heard there were stormwater comments but haven’t received them directly.
Could you share:
- Which agencies have returned comments
- Any must-fix items blocking circulation
Thanks,
[NAME] [PHONE]

Reply (Navigator) — Status summary:
- Municipal Engineering: updated hydrologic calcs for 1:10 and 1:100 storm; confirm infiltration rates using on-site testing.
- Planning: minor revision to front setback.
- Fire: turning template for truck Aerial 18 tight at SE corner; requires swept path revision.
- Env/Province: awaiting QEP memo on swale; pending but not a stop.
Blocking items: stormwater calcs + fire access. Suggest coordinated resubmission to avoid second cycle. Offer 20-min coordination call.

Follow-up (Requester):
Civil can submit by Thursday. Fire access tricky—lane width fixed.
Question: If swept path is met with a mountable curb detail, will Fire accept? Also, term sheet expires [DATE] [FINANCING]. Can we clear comments by early June if we submit this week?

Reply (Navigator):
Mountable curb has precedent; Fire typically accepts if path shows no encroachment beyond curb face and radii meet spec. Timing possible but contingent on complete package.

subject: Conflicting comments: emergency access vs. landscape buffer – 302 Harbour View Mews

goals: Resolve conflicting requirements from Fire and Planning
constraints: Site width only allows 7.3m total for drive + buffer
blockers: Parking compliance impacted if stalls removed
decision_points: Whether narrowed buffer and planting strategy is acceptable

text:
Subject: Conflicting comments: emergency access vs. landscape buffer – [ADDRESS]

From: [NAME] <[EMAIL]> | To: permits.navigator@gov.example.ca | Date: [DATE]
Hi,
We received two comments:
1) Fire: requires 6.0 m clear width for access drive.
2) Planning: retain a 2.0 m landscape buffer at the same edge.
Our site only allows 7.3 m total. We can’t satisfy both without removing visitor stalls (reduces compliance). Which requirement takes precedence?
Files:
- [ATTACHMENT] 2025-09-30_SitePlan_AltB.pdf
- [ATTACHMENT] 2025-09-30_CommentLog.xlsx
Thanks,
[NAME]

Reply (Navigator):
In safety conflicts, Fire access prevails. Common resolution: narrow landscape buffer to 1.2–1.5 m at pinch points + use columnar species for screening. Consider stall depth adjustments/overhang into landscape or restriping if allowed. Will convene Fire + Planning and return unified note.

Follow-up (Requester):
Please confirm if tapered throat geometry is acceptable for first 8 m; traffic engineer says it preserves emergency turning paths.

subject: Final checklist before BP issuance – 77 Parkcrest Lane ([FILE_NO])

goals: Confirm remaining items for BP issuance
Confirm inspection sequence and blower door requirement
decision_points: Whether mid-construction blower door is required vs recommended

text:
Subject: Final checklist before BP issuance – [ADDRESS] ([FILE_NO])

From: [NAME] <[EMAIL]> | To: permits.navigator@gov.example.ca | Date: [DATE]
Hi,
We’ve uploaded the truss shop drawings and energy compliance forms. Are there any remaining items before [FILE_NO] is issued for [ADDRESS]?
Also confirming inspection sequence: footing, foundation, framing, insulation/air barrier, final. Our GC asked whether mid-construction blower door is required under the new step code.
Thanks,
[NAME] [PHONE]

Reply (Navigator):
Remaining items:
- Letters of Assurance: A, B (Architect) and S (Structural) need original seals.
- Geotech field review commitment (over-excavation risk).
- Updated site servicing sheet showing cleanout locations.
Inspection sequence confirmed. Mid-construction blower door is recommended (not mandatory) to de-risk the final.
Once LOAs are re-uploaded, issuance can proceed.

subject: Request to expedite review due to expiring tenancy & project carry costs

constraints: Waiting on Planning while other responses completed
decision_points: Whether remaining comments can be bundled into one consolidated response cycle

text:
Subject: Request to expedite review due to expiring tenancy & project carry costs

From: [NAME] <[EMAIL]> | To: permits.navigator@gov.example.ca | Date: [DATE]
Hi,
We’re carrying significant monthly interest [FINANCING] while waiting on tree variance comments for [ADDRESS]. Our tenants in the existing duplex must vacate by [DATE] ([LEGAL]).
Is there any way to bundle the remaining comments so we can address them at once? We’ve already responded to Arborist and Engineering; just waiting on Planning.
Files:
- [ATTACHMENT] 2025-11-14_Tree_Variance_Justification.pdf
- [ATTACHMENT] 2025-11-14_Arborist_Addendum_LotA.pdf
Thank you,
[NAME]

Reply (Navigator):
Acknowledges pressures; will request consolidated comments from Planning and see if sign-off can be pulled forward. No guarantees. Will flag carry costs and tenant timeline for coordination awareness (does not adjudicate tenancy).
